Being Black in Jiu-Jitsu

May 23, 2023

Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) is a dynamic martial art that has been gaining significant traction in the global arena. It's deeply rooted in Brazil but has been quickly spreading to every corner of the world, sprouting academies everywhere. Yet, despite its far-reaching appeal, there's been a certain level of hesitation amongst individuals from the black community to dive into BJJ, particularly if they find themselves as minority members in a majority white school. In this piece, we will dive into why it is crucial for more individuals from the black community to participate in BJJ, even in majority white schools, and offer some advice on navigating potential social barriers.

The Appeal of BJJ

At the core of it, BJJ is an incredibly rewarding sport that holistically develops both mind and body. It's an art of grappling that not only instills a sense of self-defense but also imparts lessons on strength, flexibility, endurance, and mental resilience. It's also been observed to have a positive effect on mental health, acting as a stress buster and anxiety reducer, while enhancing self-esteem and general wellbeing. Given these numerous advantages, it's no surprise that a large number of people have passionately taken up the practice.

The Challenge

However, the prospect of joining a BJJ school as part of a racial minority can seem daunting for many from the black community. Although the BJJ community generally champions openness and acceptance, there are moments of ignorance and insensitivity toward people of color. This, however, should not dissuade black individuals from embracing BJJ. By being part of this community, you're not just joining a group that fosters camaraderie, discipline, and respect but you're also pushing boundaries and breaking stereotypes.

Overcoming Obstacles

One crucial aspect to remember when joining a BJJ school is the right to voice your boundaries and hold others accountable for their actions. Clear and open communication with your training partners and instructors about your expectations is key. Stand firm on your boundaries, but don't hesitate to speak out when you feel disrespected or uncomfortable. Remember, though, that these conversations need to be approached with an open mind and willingness to educate others. Sharing your personal experiences and perspectives can be a powerful tool in creating a more inclusive and respectful environment.

Tips for Navigating BJJ as a Minority

  1. Be clear and concise: When communicating your feelings and expectations, be direct and transparent. Use "I" statements to articulate your thoughts and avoid making assumptions about others' intentions.
  2. Educate others: If you encounter insensitive comments or behavior, use it as an opportunity to educate that individual about why such actions are unacceptable. Be patient and understanding, but do not hesitate to engage in these challenging conversations.
  3. Seek support: Cultivate a network of allies who understand and respect your boundaries. This can be other trainees, friends, or family members. Having a solid support system in place makes it easier to navigate difficult situations and can provide a sense of safety.
  4. Focus on your journey: Remember that your BJJ journey is about your personal growth and not about becoming a spokesperson for the entire black community. While it is important to stand up for yourself and others, don't let others' ignorance divert you from your goals.
